content:
Just got this in a clash and it is really hard to understand/read this statement.

It would be good to explain what [[xy]] is better and maybe even show an example of what you mean by "each block contains a 2-digit integer from the original message", such as "e.g. for the [[message]] {{9972450881}} and [[blockPosition]] = {{2}}, then [[xy]] is 72.

I came first in Fastest mode after 9 minutes, and 4/7 clashers got 0%. But the challenge was mostly understanding the clash, rather than coding the solution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I liked the contribution and it worked, I tried it! amazing challenge for beginners

Hey, in the Solution line 8
```py
x=int(message[(blockPosition-1)*2:blockPosition*2])
```
I still don't understand why you multiply by 2 ?
its going to overflow if you pick a block position more than half of the message
for example
```
(892347,25)
decrypt
6467
3
```
The block here is normally 67 right ?
but no it overflows cause blockPosition*2 = 3*2 = 6 (which is out of bound for message size 4)

To fix this line 8  should be
```py
x = int(message[(block_position - 1): (block_position + 1)])
```

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I liked it.

Good contribution.

I guess what you mean by "The position starts at 1" is that The position is a 1-based index ?
Probably more obvious if you say it that way.

Not a fan at the moment: i found it very confusing with lots of names, variables, and text...
- The "mod((xy)^a,n)" is not very clear because of the highlighting of the variables (i think sometimes 5dn1l goes a little bit crazy with his suggestions lol)
- Would be better to have the two ints of the key as two separate ints instead of a string containing the two ints. It makes for a very huge time difference between languages just to get the input (for instance in C i had to strtok the string two times to use atoi two times to get the two ints...). There is no reason to make people waste time on coding to get the input, the input should be given.
- No need to have both a and b, they both are ints and serve as the second int in the key. There should only be one int a, used in different positions for the mod depending on the purpose 
- The whole block position could be fun but is worded very poorly.
- "Be aware each block contains a 2-digit integer from the original message. The position starts at 1" i still don't get this lol

Overall i couldn't finish this clash and had to see your solution only to realize it was very simple, I think you have to rewrite the thing to make everything clearer and a bit simpler. 

Good luck !

Goal
* Please change "a block contains 2 numbers" to "each block contains a 2-digit integer".

* Please format "n", "a", "b" and "xy" as [[variables]].

Input
* Please add line numbers in <<bold>> in front of all the descriptions, i.e. <<Line 1>>, <<Line 2>>, etc.

* Please change "(n,a/b)" to "{{(}}[[n]]{{,}}[[a]] if public, [[b]] if private{{)}}. [[n]], [[a]] and [[b]] are all integers".

* Please format "encrypt" and "decrypt" as {{constants}}.

Output
* Please remove the quotation marks and change the format as follows:
{{The}} [{{encrypted}}/{{decrypted}}] {{message is}} [[result]]{{.}}

Constraints
* Please change the second constraint as:
Number of blocks in [[message]] ≥ [[blockPosition]]

Cases
* Test 1, Test 2, Test 4, Validator 4: Please change [[message]] so that its length is even.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. "write answer".

Thanks.
Could you match the test/validator in order to get the same purpose (either encrypt or decrypt) ?
Done! Just dind't change that in Test/Validator 4 because it tests the case in which the text has an odd length.
Done!

Well, I admit there can be a lot of formatting, but hey, the author can simplify the statement to mention fewer variable names, so there won't be so much formatting.

My preference is: As few variable names as possible in Goal section. Keep them in Input, Output and Constraints section.

But then, I'm reluctant to change the author's statement if the original is working. I can propose a drastic simplification to the statement if I want, but that's not what I want to do.
Done!
Thank you!

Of course that overflows. Since there are only 2 blocks in that message, you can’t decrypt a 3rd block. Therefore, it overflows. 

As you can see, I made tests so it doesn’t overflow. There’s no need to think about that edge case.
thanks!
Sorry for having a hard time understanding this clash and thanks for telling me how to make it better! I just made those changes that you asked for, would you mind checking if it is okay now?
Yeah, that's much better. Thanks for the quick adjustment. I think clashers will have a much easier time of solving it now.
nice :)

Never mind I apologize it's my bad 
I didn't understand the problem that well and I miscalculated that

The code is indeed right

I would've liked if the problem was more clear about the block thingy

This is what you are meaning I believe

block 1
[99]72450881

block 2
99[72]450881

I Thought block 2 was 
9[97]2450881

Which is a bit confusing thats why I told you its 1-based index
I dont know how to make this clearer but having an eg like this would help

```
block 1
[99]72450881

block 2
99[72]450881
```
can you check if you like it now?
Perfect !

1- Done!
2- I think choosing the best language should be step1 of a clash. Example: If you know you are going to change a string, you need to chose python, etc. Therefore, I don't think that making that change is appropriate for a clash. 
3- That's apart of the clash. The person coding should notice, hence why this clash is also for the shortest mode.
4/5- Already made that change, would you mind checking it out?

Thanks!

The formatting is inconsistent, which is bad.

To take @gucamuze's complaint about my "craziness" into account, I propose to rewrite the statement from the second paragraph onwards as follows, for the consideration of both of you:

Your task is to output the encrypted/decrypted message using the given information, which includes:

• a key which consists of two integers [[n]] and [[m]],

• whether your task is to {{encrypt}} or {{decrypt}},

• the encrypted/decrypted message, which are divided into blocks. Each block contains a 2-digit integer, and

• the position of the block you have to encrypt/decrypt. 1-based indexing is used.

You are given a public key if you are asked to encrypt the given message. You are given a private key if you are asked to decrypt the given message. In both cases, the <<same formula>> is used.

If the block to encrypt/decrypt is [[xy]], then the encrypted/decrypted block can be found by:
mod([[xy]]^[[m]], [[n]])

Thanks.
If my revised wording is accepted, then Line 1 of Input section should be adjusted accordingly too.

Please don't take it the wrong way 5D, I appreciate you and your hard work :) For this clash in particular it's not that much that your suggestions are crazy but the main issue is the statement being complicated and inconsistent in general.

For OP, hard disagree on your take about clashes: just because you like to swap languages for each clash doesn't mean everyone does it. Some people enjoy using only one language or only use one to challenge themselves, some people don't feel comfortable using some languages etc etc. Please don't force your opinion on how clashes should be done on other people :/

At the end of the day, while i liked the idea of this clash because it's fun and challenging, i still think it needs more work, but that's just my opinion (hence why i didn't rejected it)
Thank you, I appreciate your comment regarding me :)
Nice ! I have a contribution pending, feel free to review it if you want !
For sure!
